questions.text:
Match the following nail sign with its most likely cause

 


	
		
			
			A. Mee’s line
			
			
			1. Chronic renal insufficiency
			
		
		
			
			B. Muehrcke's lines
			
			
			2. Liver cirrhosis
			
		
		
			
			C. Lindsay's nails
			
			
			3. Arsenic poisoning
			
		
		
			
			D. Terry’s nails
			
			
			4. Hypoalbuminemia
questions.solution:
Correct answer: a) A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2


Explanation:

The above conditions are examples of leukonychia

 

Nail sign

Causes

Mees’ lines

 

Also known as transverse leukonychia.

Horizontal, transverse white lines.

Seen in,

  • Arsenic poisoning
  • Chemotherapy

 

Muehrcke’s lines

 

  • Pairs of transverse white bands.
  • Seen in Hypoalbuminemia.

Lindsay's nails

 

Also known as half-and-half nails.

 

See in:

  • Chronic renal failure
  • Uremia

 
 

Terry’s nails

 

The proximal part is white and the distal nail appears normal and red.

 

Seen in:

  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Diabetes

Punctate leukonychia

 

Seen in:

  • Trauma
  • Alopecia areata

 

Leukonychia is the whitish discoloration of nails. It can be classified as true leukonychia and false leukonychia.


 

True leukonychia

False leukonychia

Occurs due to defective keratinization of the nail matrix.

Due to abnormal nail bed vasculature.

White lines or patches over the nail that do not disappear with pressure.

Whitish discoloration disappears with pressure.

Lines or patches move distally with nail growth and eventually disappear.

Do not disappear with nail growth.

Examples: Mees’ lines, punctate lines.

Examples: Terry’s nails, Muerhcke’s nails.

questions.text: A 70 year old man presents with complaints of recent hair loss. He is currently undergoing chemotherapy treatment for acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. Scalp examination reveals significantly decreased hair density compared to the previous visit. Which stage of his hair cycle is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Anagen

 

Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis in this patient undergoing chemotherapy is Anagen effluvium, which refers to hair shedding during the anagen or growth stage of the hair cycle.

Hair goes through 3 stages in its life cycle. These stages are the

  • Anagen phase (growth phase): 86% of hair, 3 years.
  • Catagen phase (transition phase): 1% of hair, 3 weeks.
  • Telogen phase (falling phase): 10-13% of hair, 3 months.

Anagen effluvium:

  • Anagen effluvium refers to hair shedding in the growth phase of the hair cycle. In this phase, the affected hairs have a cessation in their mitotic activity, causing damage to the hair shaft that results in breakage and complete hair loss if the bulb is affected.
  • The main causes of anagen effluvium are toxic or inflammatory insults from drugs, toxins, radiation, and autoimmune diseases. Infections may interrupt hair growth, resulting in a single or several bald patches.
  • Onset is rapid after 2–3 weeks after exposure to the cause.
  • It is a diffuse, non-scarring type of alopecia that is completely reversible after the stoppage of cause, with a delay of 3–6 months. It requires no particular treatment.

 

Catagen (Option B): is incorrect because it is the transitional phase (2–3 weeks) when hair growth slows and follicular regression begins. It is not the primary target in chemotherapy-related hair loss.

 

Telogen (Option C): is incorrect because telogen effluvium refers to hair shedding due to premature shift into the resting phase, typically seen after stress, fever, or childbirth, not chemotherapy. Onset is delayed (2–3 months) after the insult.

 

Exogen (Option D): is incorrect because this is the shedding phase of telogen hairs. It is a passive process and not directly disrupted by chemotherapy agents.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man complains of progressive hair thinning over the temples and crown over the past two years. There is no history of sudden hair shedding, scarring, or itching. Examination shows a receding hairline and miniaturized hairs in the affected areas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Androgenetic alopecia

 

Explanation:

  • Androgenic alopecia, a type of non-scarring alopecia, characterized by progressive hair thinning especially at the temples and crown is typical of male-pattern baldness.


Hair loss is divided into cicatricial and non-cicatricial alopecias:

Cicatricial alopecias

Non-cicatricial alopecias

Loss of hair follicle stem cells.

Stem cells are not affected.

Irreversible cessation of hair cycle.

Damage to the hair cycle can be reversed.

Dermoscopy: Absent follicular ostia.

Dermoscopy: Ostia is present. Black dots may be seen.

Examples:

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia (Option A)
  • Folliculitis
  • Lupus erythematosus (Option D)
  • Scleroderma

Types:

  • Patterned: Androgenic alopecia
  • Diffuse: Effluvium (Option B)
  • Patchy:
    • Alopecia areata
    • Trichotillomania.
    • Tinea capitis
    • Moth-eaten alopecia.

Telogen effluvium (Option B) is a nonscarring alopecia marked by diffuse, often acute hair shedding due to metabolic stress, hormonal changes, or medication. It typically resolves once the underlying cause is addressed.

questions.text: A 32 year old man presents with a 5-week history of hair loss in a well-defined area as shown below. The hairs along the periphery of the lesion can be pulled with minimal traction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Alopecia areata

Explanation:

This patient with a positive hair pull test and patchy hair loss has alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a T-cell-mediated autoimmune condition targeting the anagen hair bulb causing non-scarring hair loss. Clinical features include,

  • Localized patches of hair loss on the scalp that emerge over a few weeks. It can also affect other areas, such as the beard, eyebrows, eyelashes, and extremities.
  • Variants:
    • Alopecia Totalis: Complete hair loss from the scalp.
    • Alopecia Universalis: Complete hair loss from all over the body.
    • Ophiasis: Occipital hair loss.

Alopecia Totalis

  • Exclamation-mark hair, with a narrower proximal end than the distal end, is commonly observed at the periphery of lesions and is a pathognomonic finding in patients with alopecia areata.
  • Pitting of nails that is superficial, geometric and regular

Patchy hair loss

Yellow dots and exclamation mark hair

Pitting of nails

The pull test is positive, Very gentle traction on the unaffected hair at the margin of the patch of hair loss can remove all of the hair from the roots painlessly. It is a distinguishing feature of alopecia areata

Traction alopecia (Option A): Because of traction, there is an excess force applied to the hair follicle causing traction alopecia. On the hair pull test, it is not possible to remove the hair with a gentle tug. The patient will have a previous history of hairstyling or wearing wigs.

Tinea capitis (Option C): Pull test, Hair may break off, but it is not removed completely. There will be other symptoms like irritation and itching.

Telogen effluvium (Option D): During stress, hair in the anagen phase prematurely converts into the telogen phase, causing hair loss. Only a fraction of the hair can be removed by gentle traction and past history is significant for stress.

questions.text: A 28 year old female presents with concerns about hair loss and decreased hair volume, as shown below. Many members of her family also have a similar history of significant hair loss. All of the following are true about the given condition except?

choices.text: It follows a polygenic mode of inheritance.
Ludwig’s grading system is used to assess severity.
Mitochondrial inheritance is the primary mode of transmission.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Mitochondrial inheritance is the primary mode of transmission.

 

Explanation:

Hair loss with increased central parting and decreased hair volume is considered to be female pattern hair loss (FPHL). It is different from female pattern baldness as there is no loss of front hairline (Option A).

  • It is seen in androgenetic alopecia which occurs due to the involvement of multiple hormonal and genetic factors. Multiple genes have been identified for the same and hence it is considered to be of polygenic inheritance (Option B).
  • It is commonly seen in middle-aged women with progressive loss of terminal hair over the vertex of the scalp.
  • It presents with diffuse thinning of hair, increased hair shedding, decreased hair volume, and widening of hair partition.
  • Grade 3 FPHL is also called the ‘Fir tree / Christmas tree’ pattern.
  • Ludwig’s grading for female androgenic alopecia. (Option C)

Treatment: Topical 2% minoxidil is the first line of treatment, with or without adjuncts like spironolactone in women and finasteride in men.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presents with concern about hair loss and gradual thinning, as seen in the picture given below. He reports that all the male members of his family has lost their hair by 45 years, What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Androgenic alopecia

 

Explanation:

The patient presents with concerns about hair loss and hair thinning, with the family history suggesting the diagnosis of male pattern baldness in this patient.

Male pattern hair loss (androgenetic alopecia) is common in men, characterized by progressive loss of terminal hairs on the scalp, influenced by genetics and hormones. It typically begins at the temples and crown, progressing with age.

Dihydrotestosterone (DHT), derived from testosterone, shrinks hair follicles, reducing the anagen phase and miniaturizing hair. This leads to the transformation of thick terminal hair into finer, vellus hair.

Symptoms include hair thinning and bitemporal recession of the hairline

Bitemporal recession → vertex balding → Finally left with a band of hair in the occipital region because this area is androgen-independent.

Grading: Hamilton Norwood grading

Treatment:

  • Topical treatment: Minoxidil 5%
  • Systemic: Oral 5-alpha reductase inhibitors(finasteride, dutasteride)
  • Surgical: Hair transplantation

Alopecia areata (Option C) is an autoimmune condition where the immune system mistakenly attacks hair follicles, leading to sudden, round patches of hair loss. This is not consistent with the given clinical scenario.

Pseudopelade of Brocq (Option D):

  • Pseudopelade of Brocq (PPB) is a rare, idiopathic self-limiting hair disorder resulting in progressive cicatricial alopecia.
  • Footprints in snow appearance.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman has been complaining of patchy scalp hair loss for the past three weeks. Her past medical history is significant for vitiligo and thyroid disorders. On examination, she has a well-circumscribed area of hair loss over her occipital region, as shown below. Which among the following is not a feature of the disease described?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Trichoclasis

 

Explanation:

This patient with a history of autoimmune diseases and patchy hair loss as described in the question and image is suggestive of alopecia areata.

Trichoclasis is a feature of a feature of trichorrhexis nodosa, not alopecia areata.

Trichoclasis:

  • It is a transverse break in the hair shaft through a node seen in Trichorrhexis nodosa.
  • It is a hair shaft disorder where the hair shaft is excessively fragile due to the presence of nodes.
  • The end of the hair resembles a small paint brush with cortical fibers extruding through the fracture as shown in the image.
  • The proximal end of the hair shaft is normal, unlike in alopecia areata.

 

  • It is associated with rare genetic diseases like argininosuccinate lyase deficiency.
  • Clinical features: Sparse, brittle, and lustreless hair
  • Diagnosis is through physical examination and hair shaft microscopy
  • Treatment includes avoiding trauma to the hair and management of the medical cause.

 

The features of alopecia areata include

  • Ophiasis is scalp hair loss in the occipital region, whereas sisaipho is the opposite of this variant, with scalp hair loss sparing the temporal and occipital areas.
Ophiasis Sisaipho


 

  • Exclamation mark hair
  • Turning grey syndrome: It is a feature of alopecia areata where white hair are typically spared by immune cells, leading to loss of black hair with sparing of white hair
  • Nail pitting: Regular, geometric pitting of the nail bed as shown below.

Note: Psoriasis shows irregular pitting.

Treatment depends on the extent of the disease. Topical therapy for limited disease is done using intralesional steroids and contact immunotherapy whereas systemic therapy, Levamisole or Cyclosporine is used for extensive disease.

questions.text:
The image shows a 16 year old boy brought to the clinic by his father with an unusual pattern of hair loss. History states that he has become increasingly reclusive, avoiding family gatherings and showing less interest in his usual hobbies spending most of his time alone in his room. The boy himself appears unaware of the issue and has no complaints.



 

What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Trichotillomania


Explanation:

The boy with the above history and a characteristic Friar Tuck hair loss pattern has trichotillomania.

Trichotillomania:

  • It is a psychiatric disorder in which obsessive, recurrent pulling of one’s hair results in hair loss.
  • It is seen in adolescents or young adults, more commonly in girls.
  • Patchy hair loss with broken hair of variable lengths is seen in commonly accessible sites like the frontoparietal area of the scalp.
  • In the Friar Tuck sign or Tonsure pattern, there is uneven hair loss in a circular pattern with surrounding hairs remaining unaffected.

  • Perifollicular hemorrhages can also be seen because of trauma to the scalp.
  • Skin biopsy shows empty hair follicles, with some forming soft twisted hairs described as tracheomalacia.
  • Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy and antipsychotic medications like SSRI and paroxetine.
  • Trichobezoar/ Rapunzel syndrome is caused by chronic ingestion of hair; it is commonly seen in young females who may have psychological disorders, such as trichophagia and trichotillomania. Common symptoms are abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.

Netherton syndrome (Option D) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the serine protease inhibitor. Characteristic triad includes,

  • Congenital Ichtyosiform erythroderma.
  • Trichorrhexis invaginata (Bamboo hair).
  • Atopic diathesis.

Alopecia areata (Option B) is an autoimmune condition where the immune system mistakenly attacks hair follicles, leading to sudden, round patches of hair loss. This is not consistent with the given clinical scenario.

Pseudopelade of Brocq (Option C) is a chronic and slowly progressive idiopathic condition with no inflammation, scaling, or erythema.

  • Smooth patches due to scarring alopecia.
  • Footprint in snow appearance-spreading patches of cicatricial alopecia.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with a history of recurrent painful, pustular lesions on scalp which heals with scarring. She is healthy otherwise with no history of similar lesions. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?

choices.text: The culture of extracted hair alone.
Culture of extracted hair with patient-collected hair sheddings.
Shave biopsy of scalp and culture of extracted hair.
Punch biopsy of scalp and culture of extracted hair.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Punch biopsy of scalp and culture of extracted hair

 

Explanation:

The patient presented with a history of recurrent painful, pustular lesions on the scalp which heal with scarring suggests the diagnosis of Folliculitis decalvans. A punch biopsy of the scalp and culture of extracted hair is the most appropriate investigation.

Folliculitis decalvans:

  • Folliculitis decalvans or tufted hair folliculitis is a progressive pattern of cicatricial alopecia of the scalp.
  • Its characteristic feature is the presence of multiple tufts of hair emerging from a single follicular opening also known as Doll’s hair appearance
  • The images below depict the scaring alopecia seen in Folliculitis decalvans.

 

  • Diagnosis is based on clinical and histological findings. Ideal biopsy tissue should contain clinical signs of scarring, no follicular ostia, and active inflammation (pustules, erythema, etc.).
  • Hence, a punch biopsy that extends into the subcutaneous fat is our preferred procedure for the pathologic evaluation of FD.
  • Oral antibiotics (Tetracyclines) are the mainstay treatment.

questions.text: A 32 year old man complains of multiple inflamed, fluctuating nodules on his scalp. He also has patchy areas of hair loss. Upon examination, you notice interconnected sinus tracts and scarring with pustular discharge as shown below. Which of the following is not associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Pustular psoriasis

 

Explanation:

The above scenario with scalp lesions is seen in dissecting cellulitis of the scalp, which is part of the follicular occlusion tetrad. Pustular psoriasis is not part of the tetrad.

Follicular occlusion tetrad is a group of four disorders where follicular occlusion is thought to be a key pathogenic event. The components of this tetrad are:

  1. Dissecting cellulitis of the scalp
  2. Hidradenitis suppurativa
  3. Acne conglobata
  4. Pilonidal sinus


Dissecting cellulitis of the scalp:

  • Dissecting cellulitis of the scalp (Hoffman disease) is a type of cicatricial alopecia characterized by multiple suppurative nodular lesions over the scalp.
  • Follicular occlusion by accumulation of sebaceous and keratinous materials causes an intense neutrophilic inflammatory reaction which is exacerbated by secondary bacterial infection.
  • The patient presents with boggy, suppurative pustules and nodules that later form sinus tracts. This leads to patchy and scarring alopecia over the scalp as shown below.
  • Diagnosis is mainly clinical through history and examination.
  • Cultures are done to determine the organism causing secondary infection.

 

Treatment:

  • Treatment is started with oral antibiotics and/or oral isotretinoin.
  • Biologic tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha inhibitors and surgical excision are options in patients who don’t respond to earlier treatment.

questions.text:
Match the sign with its associated hair disorder:


	
		
			
			a. Pseudopelade of Brocq
			
			
			i. Scaly & itchy violaceous lesions
			
		
		
			
			b. Folliculitis decalvans
			
			
			ii. Doll’s hair sign
			
		
		
			
			c. Follicular lichen planus
			
			
			iii. Patches with scales & follicular plugging
			
		
		
			
			d. Lupus erythematosus
			
			
			iv. Footprint in snow sign
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) a-iv, b-ii, c-i, d-iii


Explanation:

Pseudopelade of Brocq

  • Chronic and slowly progressive idiopathic condition with no inflammation, scaling, or erythema.
  • Smooth patches due to scarring alopecia.
  • Footprint in snow appearance-spreading patches of cicatricial alopecia.

Footprint in snow sign

Folliculitis decalvans

  • Deep folliculitis caused by bacteria.
  • Pustules with neutrophilic infiltrate damage the stem cells causing cicatricial alopecia.
  • Doll’s hair sign - Multiple hair tufts emerge from the common dilated follicular opening.

Doll’s hair sign

Follicular LP / Lichen plano pilaris

  • Violaceous plaques in the perifollicular distribution.
  • Itching present.

Scaly & itchy violaceous lesions

Lupus erythematosus

  • Scarred patches of alopecia are associated with scaling and follicular plugging.
  • A positive history of lupus may be present.

Patches with scales & follicular plugging

questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents with complaints of abnormal hair growth, as shown in the image. Which of the following drugs can be prescribed to her as oral therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Spironolactone

 

Explanation:

  • The given image shows coarse terminal hair in the face region of a woman, which suggests hirsutism. Among the given options, spironolactone is a popular treatment for hirsutism. It interferes with the production of testosterone and increases its metabolic clearance.
  • Hirsutism refers to excessive terminal hair growth in women, which is an initial sign of a hyperandrogenic state. The hair growth is in a male pattern, occurring as a response to the presence of higher levels of testosterone. The vellus hair turns into coarse, terminal hairs.

  • The Ferriman-Gallwey (mFG) score is a method for evaluating and quantifying hirsutism, or excess body or facial hair growth, in women.An Ferriman-Gallwey score of 8 or more was considered diagnostic of hirsutism.
     

Causes:

  • SAHA syndrome
  • PCOS
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Ovarian tumours
  • Acquired adrenocortical disease
  • Idiopathic hirsutism


 

Management:

Topical
  • Eflornithine

Anti-androgen drugs
  • Spironolactone
  • OCPs If the patient has PCOS.
  • Dutasteride
  • Flutamide
  • Cyproterone acetate

Physical
  • Hair removal lasers
  • Diode and long pulse ND Yag laser


Danazol. Tamoxifen & Phenytoin (Options A, B & C) are drugs responsible for causing hirsutism.

questions.text:
A 32 year old female presents with complaints of breathlessness, weakness, and fatigue for the past few months. She has no significant past history. On examination, she appears to have some nail changes as depicted in the image below.



What would be the most appropriate investigation to verify the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Serum iron level

 

Explanation:

The patient presented with complaints of breathlessness, weakness, and fatigue for the past few weeks and has spoon-shaped nails (koilonychia), as shown in the image, suggesting iron deficiency anemia.Koilonychia is most commonly a manifestation of chronic iron deficiency.Iron deficiency anemia is primarily a laboratory diagnosis. Low serum iron and ferritin levels plus an elevated total iron binding capacity (TIBC) are diagnostic of iron deficiency.

Other causes of koilonychia include

  • Pulmonary and thoracic causes- Bronchogenic carcinoma, suppurative lung disease (bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, lung abscess, empyema), interstitial lung disease, long-standing pulmonary TB.
  • Gastrointestinal causes- Cirrhosis of the liver, UC, Crohn’s disease.
  • Cardiovascular causes- Cyanotic congenital heart disease, bacterial endocarditis, atrial myxoma, and Eisenmeger’s syndrome.


LFTs (Option A) are useful in diagnosing Terry’s nails. It's a type of leukonychia, where the proximal part is white and the distal nail appears normal and red. It is seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, T2DM, and some other autoimmune diseases.


Serum albumin (Option B) can be useful in the diagnosis of Muehrcke's lines on nails, which are transverse, white bands that run across the nail. These are typically associated with hypoalbuminemia in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Chest X-ray (Option C): Clubbing refers to increased longitudinal and transverse curvatures of the nail plate. Clubbing is commonly associated with pulmonary and cardiovascular diseases such as lung cancer, congenital heart disease, pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis, and infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A 25 year old woman presents with complaints of the following nail lesions. Which among the following might be the most likely cause of the same?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Lichen planus

Explanation:

The above image shows a wing-shaped extension of the proximal nail fold on the nail plate suggestive of pterygium seen in the Lichen planus (LP) of the nail.

The other image shows Trachyonychia of the nail. It presents as a rough surface affecting all of the nail plate (sand-blasted nails).

Nail presentation in LP includes:

  • Longitudinal ridging, nail plate thinning, longitudinal fissuring.
  • Pterygium occurs secondary to scarring of the nail matrix.
  • Trachonychia: Other causes of trachyonychia include idiopathic changes and alopecia areata.


Burns and Blunt force trauma (Option B and Option C) present with Pterygium but not Trachyonychia.

Scleroderma (Option D) presents with Inverse Pterygium. In this condition, the hyponychium attaches to the nail distally. Other causes include connective tissue disorders, trauma, scleroderma, SLE, and Raynaud's syndrome.

questions.text: A 42 year old male patient presents with numbness and tingling sensation over his soles. O/E, there are areas of hyperpigmentation, along with skin thickening on the palms and soles. The following findings are seen in his nails. Which of the following heavy metals could be responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Arsenic


Explanation:

The given scenario with transverse, white bands that run parallel on the nail suggests a case of chronic arsenic poisoning. Chronic exposure to arsenic results in peripheral neuropathy, vascular insufficiency and various malignancies. Cutaneous manifestations include Mee's lines, arsenic keratosis, eczema and gangrene.

Arsenic keratosis

 

Mee's lines


Acute arsenic poisoning presents with severe nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain and diarrhoea.

Causes: Contaminated Groundwater, tobacco, industrial areas, and food.

Investigations: Basophilic stippling, increased urinary coprobilinogen III level, a radioopaque shadow in the abdomen, and increased arsenic levels in the blood.

Treatment:

  • Gastric lavage with warm saline
  • Freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide (chemical antidote)
  • Chelating agents
    • Oral: DMSA
    • IM : British anti-Lewisite (BAL) (dimercaprol)

 

Lead (Option B):

  • Lead is a common heavy metal additive found in paints, and chronic exposure can lead to lead poisoning.
  • It presents with features of nausea, diarrhoea, weakness, tremors anaemia, headache, memory disturbances and visual defects.
  • Burton's line is a classical sign on examination. It is a bluish line present on the gums in chronic lead poisoning.

 

Mercury (Option C):

  • Poisoning from mercury can occur due to inorganic sources like thermometers or organic mercury in fish (Minamata disease in Japan).
  • Mercury poisoning presents with tremors, excessive salivation, Erethism (Personality and memory disorders), and membranous glomerulopathy.

 

Cadmium (Option D):

Cadmium toxicity occurs commonly in people handling old metal pipes, batteries, polluted water, electric cigarettes, and areas with high air pollution. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, chest pain, flu-like symptoms, and shortness of breath. It can also lead to pneumonitis, osteoporosis, and chronic kidney disease.
